article text: ...By Dorcas Funmi for TDPel Media.  Pastor Iyke Ezekiel and his wife Doris Ezekiel, a Nigerian couple, have finally welcomed a baby girl after patiently waiting for 20 years.  Advertisement  The news of their long-awaited blessing was shared by Pastor Yinka Yusuf, the General Overseer of the Household of God Church in Lagos State, and his wife, Rose Yusuf, on Facebook.  The couple expressed their joy and gratitude following the child dedication ceremony held on Sunday, May 21, 2023.  In a Facebook post, Pastor Yinka Yusuf wrote, “After 20 years of waiting, God blessed my beloved son Pastor Iyke, the Pastor of our Abuja household of love church, and his beautiful wife Doris with a wonderful baby, and I was there in Abuja this morning to dedicate the baby.  Miracles are forever, and you are next in line for a Miracle.”  Similarly, Pastor Rose Yusuf shared her excitement and faith, saying, “What a joy as we dedicate our beautiful granddaughter, the child of our son and daughter, Pastor Iyke and Pastor Doris, after waiting for 20 years! Our God is a faithful God! That you have not testified does not mean that God has forgotten you, but it is just that God is on His way to you.  Our God never fails! Miracles happen turn by turn, so if your neighbor is rejoicing, rejoice with them because you are next in line for a miracle.”  The child dedication ceremony marked a moment of celebration and gratitude for the Ezekiel family.  Advertisement  The photos from the event captured the joyous occasion, showcasing the love and happiness radiating from the proud parents and their beautiful baby girl.  Advertisement

The Significance of Mount Gerizim in the Bible  Mount Gerizim is a mountain located in the northern part of ancient Israel, in the region of Samaria. It is situated near the city of Shechem, which was an important religious and cultural center in biblical times. Mount Gerizim plays a significant role in several biblical events and is mentioned dozens of times throughout the Old Testament.  Mount Gerizim in the Old Testament  In the Old Testament, Mount Gerizim is most notably associated with the story of the Israelites entering the promised land. In Deuteronomy 27-28, God instructs the Israelites to perform a special ceremony upon entering the land, where they are to recite blessings and curses. The ceremony took place on two mountains: Mount Gerizim and Mount Ebal. The Israelites stood on Mount Gerizim to recite the blessings, while they stood on Mount Ebal to recite the curses.  Mount Gerizim was also the site of the Samaritan temple, which was believed by Samaritans to be the true location where God chose to place his name. The Samaritans are a people who live in modern-day Israel, Palestine, and Jordan and have their own unique religious beliefs. They claim that their version of the Torah is the true text of the first five books of the Old Testament, and their religion is based on the worship of God at Mount Gerizim.  Mount Gerizim in the New Testament  Mount Gerizim is mentioned several times in the New Testament, primarily in the gospel of John. In John 4: 5-42, Jesus travels through Samaria and meets a Samaritan woman at a well near Mount Gerizim. They engage in a lengthy conversation, and Jesus reveals himself to the woman as the Messiah. This event is significant because it marks the first time in the gospel of John that Jesus explicitly identifies himself as the Messiah.  Mount Gerizim is also mentioned in Acts 8: 4-8, where Philip preaches the gospel in Samaria and performs miracles. The text specifically mentions that there was great joy in the city of Samaria when Philip arrived, and many believed in Jesus Christ.  Frequently Asked Questions  What is the significance of Mount Gerizim in the Samaritan religion?  Mount Gerizim is considered the most holy site in the Samaritan religion. According to Samaritan tradition, God chose Mount Gerizim as the place where Abraham was commanded to sacrifice his son Isaac. The mountain is also considered the location of the Samaritan temple, which was destroyed by the Babylonians in 586 BC. Today, the Samaritans still think of Mount Gerizim as a sacred site and perform religious ceremonies and pilgrimages to the mountain.  What is the connection between Mount Gerizim and the Samaritan woman in John 4?  The story in John 4:5-42 describes Jesus’ encounter with a Samaritan woman at a well near Mount Gerizim. The story is significant because Jesus reveals himself to the woman as the Messiah, despite the fact that she is a Samaritan. This event challenges the religious and cultural norms of Jesus’ time and shows that God’s love is available to everyone.  What was the significance of the ceremony on Mount Gerizim and Mount Ebal in Deuteronomy 27-28?  The ceremony on Mount Gerizim and Mount Ebal was a way for the Israelites to show their commitment to God and to the laws he had given them. The blessings and curses recited on the two mountains were meant to remind the Israelites of the consequences of either obeying or disobeying God’s commands. The ceremony was a powerful way for the Israelites to renew their covenant with God and to recommit themselves to following his laws.  Why did the Israelites stand on two mountains during the ceremony in Deuteronomy 27-28?  The Israelites stood on two mountains during the ceremony in order to symbolize the two sides of the covenant they had made with God. The blessings pronounced on Mount Gerizim represented the rewards of following God’s laws, while the curses pronounced on Mount Ebal represented the punishments for disobeying them. The Israelites were reminded that following God’s laws would bring blessings and joy, while disobeying them would bring curses and sorrow.  What was the significance of the temple on Mount Gerizim in Samaritan religion?  The temple on Mount Gerizim was the most important religious site in Samaritan religion. Samaritans believed that it was built by Moses himself, and that it was the true location where God had chosen to place his name. The temple was destroyed by the Babylonians in 586 BC, but Samaritans still view Mount Gerizim as a sacred site. They perform ceremonies and pilgrimages to the mountain in order to honor God and to connect with their religious history.  What is the historical significance of Mount Gerizim?  Mount Gerizim has played an important role in the history of the Middle East for thousands of years. It was a sacred site in both Jewish and Samaritan religion, and was the location of important religious ceremonies and pilgrimages. The mountain was also strategically important, as it provided a natural defense against invading armies. Today, Mount Gerizim is still an important site for religious and cultural events, and is considered one of the most historically significant sites in the Middle East.  Is Mount Gerizim mentioned in any other religious texts besides the Bible?  Mount Gerizim is not mentioned in any other major religious texts besides the Bible. However, it is referenced in several ancient Near Eastern texts and inscriptions. These texts provide insight into the historical and cultural significance of the mountain, and show that it was an important site long before the emergence of Judaism or Christianity.  What is the connection between Mount Gerizim and the city of Shechem?  Mount Gerizim is located near the city of Shechem, which was an important religious and cultural center in ancient Israel. Shechem is mentioned several times throughout the Old Testament, and was the site of many important events, such as the covenant between God and Abraham and the dividing of the kingdom after Solomon’s death. Mount Gerizim and Shechem were intimately connected in ancient times, and the mountain played an important role in the religious and cultural life of the city.  What is the current status of Mount Gerizim?  Mount Gerizim is located in the West Bank and is under Israeli military occupation. The mountain is currently home to several Israeli settlements, as well as a number of Palestinian villages. The Samaritan community still performs religious ceremonies and pilgrimages to the mountain, despite the difficulties they face accessing the site. The ongoing conflict in the region has made it difficult for the mountain to be accessed and enjoyed as a religious or cultural site by people of all faiths.  Why is Mount Gerizim significant in the gospel of John?  Mount Gerizim is significant in the gospel of John because it is the location of the well where Jesus meets the Samaritan woman in John 4:5-42. This encounter is significant because it challenges the religious and cultural norms of Jesus’ time, and shows that God’s love is available to everyone. The story also reveals the identity of Jesus as the Messiah, which is a central theme throughout the gospel of John.  What evidence is there for the existence of the Samaritan temple on Mount Gerizim?  There is strong archaeological evidence for the existence of the Samaritan temple on Mount Gerizim. Excavations on the site have revealed a number of artifacts and structures that date back to the time of the temple, including a massive staircase, a large platform, and several water cisterns. These findings support the Samaritan claims that the temple was situated on the mountain, and provide valuable insight into the religious practices of the Samaritans in ancient times.  What is the connection between Mount Gerizim and the story of Abraham and Isaac?  According to Samaritan tradition, Mount Gerizim is the location where God commanded Abraham to sacrifice his son Isaac. This story is similar to the story in the Bible, which takes place on Mount Moriah. Samaritans believe that Mount Gerizim is the true location of the event, and the mountain remains an important site for religious ceremonies and pilgrimages to this day.  What was the religious significance of Mount Gerizim in ancient Israel?  Mount Gerizim was an important religious site in ancient Israel, and was associated with the blessings and curses ceremony described in Deuteronomy 27-28. The mountain was also near the important city of Shechem, which was an important religious and cultural center at the time. Mount Gerizim was regarded as a sacred site by the ancient Israelites, and played an important role in the country’s religious and cultural life.

When Did Mary Die?  The question of when Mary died has been a topic of much debate and speculation over the years. Mary, also known as Mary of Nazareth or the Virgin Mary, was the mother of Jesus Christ and an important figure in Christianity. While the exact year of her death is not known, it is believed to have occurred somewhere between 41 and 48 AD. Some sources suggest that she lived to be around 50-60 years old.  There is no clear evidence as to the cause of Mary’s death. Some believe that she died of natural causes related to old age, while others suggest that she may have succumbed to an illness or disease. There are also some legends and traditions that suggest she was martyred or killed for her beliefs, though this is not supported by historical evidence.  Despite the lack of clear information about Mary’s death, her legacy as an important religious figure lives on. She is revered by millions of Christians around the world for her role as the mother of Jesus and for her devotion to God.  Frequently Asked Questions About Mary’s Death  1) Did Mary die a natural death?  While it is not known for certain, it is believed that Mary died of natural causes related to old age.  2) Was Mary martyred?  There is no evidence to support the claim that Mary was martyred or killed for her beliefs.  3) How old was Mary when she died?  Mary’s exact age at the time of her death is not known, but it is believed that she lived to be around 50-60 years old.  4) Where did Mary die?  There is no definitive answer as to where Mary died, but some traditions suggest that it may have been in Ephesus, modern-day Turkey.  5) When did Mary become an important figure in Christianity?  Mary’s importance in Christianity dates back to the origins of the religion itself, as she is the mother of Jesus Christ and a central figure in the story of his life and teachings.  6) How did Mary impact Christianity?  Mary’s role as the mother of Jesus and her devotion to God have made her a revered figure in Christianity, inspiring devotion and worship among millions of followers around the world.  7) Is Mary mentioned in the Bible?  Yes, Mary is mentioned numerous times in the Bible, both in the New Testament and in some prophetic texts in the Old Testament.  8) Was Mary always considered a saint in Christianity?  Mary’s status as a saint in Christianity developed over time, with her veneration increasing in the early centuries of the religion. Today, she is considered one of the most important saints in the Catholic Church.  9) Are there any miracles associated with Mary?  There are numerous miracles attributed to Mary in Christian tradition, including her appearance to the peasant Juan Diego in Mexico in the 16th century.  10) What is the significance of Mary’s death for Christians?  Mary’s death is significant for Christians because it marks the end of her earthly life and her passage into eternal life with God. It is also a reminder of the impermanence of human life and the importance of living a virtuous and devoted existence.  11) What is the Assumption of Mary?  The Assumption of Mary is a Catholic doctrine that holds that Mary was assumed bodily into heaven at the end of her earthly life. This belief is not universally held by all Christian denominations.  12) How is Mary venerated in different parts of the world?  Mary is venerated in many different ways in different parts of the world, with numerous festivals, processions, and dedications in her honor. She is particularly revered in countries such as Mexico, where she is the patron saint of the nation.

Introduction  Jesus Christ is one of the most influential religious figures who have ever lived in history. He is widely known for his teachings, miracles, and selfless sacrifice for humanity. However, before His crucifixion, Jesus faced several trials and tribulations that tested both His faith and courage.  The Trials of Jesus  The Gospels of Matthew, Mark, Luke, and John document the last days of Jesus Christ leading up to His crucifixion. Here are some of the major trials that Jesus faced before His death.  The Betrayal of Judas Iscariot  One of Jesus’ most trusted disciples, Judas Iscariot, betrayed him by identifying Him to Roman guards for thirty pieces of silver. He led the guards to the Garden of Gethsemane, where Jesus had gone to pray, and pointed Him out to the soldiers, who then arrested him.  The Trial before the Sanhedrin  Jesus was taken before the Sanhedrin, the Jewish council of religious leaders, where He was charged with blasphemy and sentenced to death. The religious leaders accused Him of speaking against God, claiming that He was the son of God, which they saw as a blatant blasphemy under Jewish law.  The Trial before Pontius Pilate  To execute Jesus, the Jewish leaders needed permission from the Roman governor of Jerusalem, Pontius Pilate. Pilate found Jesus innocent of all charges but, being afraid of the Jewish people’s rebellion, decided to hand Him over to the Jewish leaders to be crucified.  The Scourging of Jesus  Before His crucifixion, Jesus was beaten, tortured and flogged with a whip for several hours in an event known as the “scourging.” This was meant to further degrade and humiliate Him, as well as to weaken Him physically.  The Crucifixion of Jesus  Jesus was eventually led to Golgotha, where He was nailed to a wooden cross and left to hang until He died. The crucifixion was brutal and agonizing and is recognized as one of the most painful forms of execution in history.  Frequently Asked Questions  1. Why did Jesus have to die?  Jesus’ death was a vital part of God’s plan to save humanity. It is believed that Jesus’ sacrifice on the cross paid for all the sins of humankind, thereby reconciling them with God, allowing them to be forgiven and receive eternal life.  2. What did Jesus say when he was on the cross?  Jesus is famously said to have uttered several statements while on the cross, the most poignant of which was, “Father, forgive them, for they know not what they do” (Luke 23:34). He also said, “My God, my God, why have you forsaken me?” (Mark 15:34) at one point.  3. Who helped Jesus carry his cross?  A man named Simon of Cyrene was made to help Jesus carry His cross to the hill of Golgotha. According to the Gospel account, Simon was in Jerusalem for the Passover festival when he encountered Jesus.  4. How many people were crucified with Jesus?  Two criminals, one on either side of Jesus, were crucified alongside Him. One of the criminals abused Jesus, whereas the other asked Him to remember him when He enters His kingdom.  5. Where was Jesus buried?  Jesus was buried in a new tomb carved out of rock, owned by Joseph of Arimathea, a member of the Sanhedrin and a secret disciple of Jesus. The tomb was located near Golgotha.  6. When did Jesus rise from the dead?  Jesus rose from the dead on the third day after His crucifixion. This event is known as the Resurrection, and it is believed to be the cornerstone of the Christian faith.  7. What is the significance of the crown of thorns?  The crown of thorns is believed to have been placed on Jesus’ head during His journey to the cross. It is a symbol of the pain that He endured on our behalf and has become an iconic image of the crucifixion.  8. What are the Stations of the Cross?  The Stations of the Cross are fourteen events that took place during Jesus’ journey to the crucifixion. These are often depicted in churches through paintings or sculptures and are meant to evoke a sense of the suffering that Jesus underwent.  9. Why is Good Friday called “good”?  Good Friday is the day that commemorates the crucifixion of Jesus. Although it marks a tragic event, it is called “good” because of the hope that it represents: the hope of redemption and eternal life.  10. What is the significance of the cross in Christianity?  The cross is the most recognizable symbol of Christianity, signifying Jesus’ sacrifice for humankind. It reminds believers of the love that Jesus had for them and the salvation they can receive through Him.  11. Did Jesus feel pain on the cross?  Yes, Jesus would have experienced extreme pain on the cross. Crucifixion is one of the most agonizing ways to die, and Jesus’ experience would have been no different.  12. How does Jesus’ sacrifice impact my life today?  Jesus’ sacrifice on the cross offers believers the hope of forgiveness and eternal life. Through His death and resurrection, Jesus has made it possible for people to be reconciled with God and live a life of purpose and meaning.

The Story of Zechariah and Elizabeth in the Bible  Zechariah and Elizabeth are two key figures in the Bible, known for their faith and dedication to God. According to the Gospel of Luke, they were both descendants of Aaron, making them part of the priestly class in Israel. Zechariah was a priest who served in the temple in Jerusalem, and Elizabeth was his wife. They were both old and childless, a source of great pain and shame in their culture.  One day, while Zechariah was serving in the temple, an angel appeared to him and announced that his prayers had been answered: Elizabeth would conceive and bear a son, who would be named John. Zechariah was skeptical, given their age, and asked for a sign. The angel responded by striking him mute until the day of John’s birth.  Despite the challenges presented by their advanced age and social status, Zechariah and Elizabeth remained faithful to God and saw his promises fulfilled. Elizabeth did conceive and gave birth to John, who grew up to become John the Baptist, a prophet and forerunner of Jesus.  FAQs about Zechariah and Elizabeth  1. Why was Zechariah struck mute?  Zechariah was struck mute by the angel who announced John’s birth after he expressed doubt about the possibility of Elizabeth conceiving a child in their old age. The mute period was a sign of his unbelief and a means of confirming the angel’s message.  2. How did Elizabeth feel about her childlessness?  Elizabeth was deeply grieved by her inability to conceive and bear a child, a source of shame and ridicule in their culture. However, she remained faithful to God and prayed for his intervention.  3. Who was John the Baptist?  John the Baptist was the son of Zechariah and Elizabeth. He grew up to become a prophet who heralded the coming of the messiah, Jesus Christ.  4. What was the significance of John’s birth and mission?  John’s birth was a miraculous sign of God’s power and his faithfulness to his promises. John was also called to prepare the way for Jesus by preaching a message of repentance and baptism.  5. Why was John called “the Baptist”?  John was called “the Baptist” because he baptized people in the Jordan River as a sign of repentance and their preparation for the coming of the messiah.  6. What was the relationship between John and Jesus?  John and Jesus were cousins, and John was called to prepare the way for Jesus by recognizing him as the messiah and bearing witness to him.  7. Did Zechariah and Elizabeth have other children besides John?  The Bible does not mention any other children born to Zechariah and Elizabeth besides John.  8. How were Zechariah and Elizabeth viewed in their culture?  Being old and childless was considered a curse in their culture, and Zechariah and Elizabeth likely faced shame and ridicule because of this. However, their faithfulness to God and the miraculous birth of John brought them honor and recognition.  9. What can we learn from Zechariah and Elizabeth’s story?  We can learn the importance of faith and perseverance in the face of difficult circumstances. Zechariah and Elizabeth’s story demonstrates that God is faithful to his promises and can work miracles even when situations seem impossible.  10. Why are Zechariah and Elizabeth important figures in the Bible?  Zechariah and Elizabeth are important figures in the Bible because they played a key role in the birth and mission of John the Baptist, who prepared the way for Jesus Christ. Their story also illustrates the power of faith and the miraculous interventions of God.  11. How can we apply the story of Zechariah and Elizabeth to our lives today?  We can apply the story of Zechariah and Elizabeth to our lives today by trusting in God’s promises and having faith in his power to work miracles in our lives. We can also learn from their example of perseverance and dedication to God’s plan.  12. What is the legacy of Zechariah and Elizabeth?  The legacy of Zechariah and Elizabeth is their unwavering faith and obedience to God, which resulted in the miraculous birth of John the Baptist and his important missions. Their story also continues to inspire and encourage believers to trust in God’s power and faithfulness.

Why Did Jesus Heal on the Sabbath?  The Sabbath was considered a day of rest in Jewish tradition. As a result, it was forbidden to do any work on that day, including healing. However, Jesus often chose to heal people on the Sabbath. This decision raised many questions and concerns among the religious leaders of his time.  One reason Jesus might have healed on the Sabbath was to show that the Sabbath was made for humanity, not the other way around. Jesus emphasized this point in Mark 2:27, where he said, “The Sabbath was made for man, not man for the Sabbath.” By performing healing miracles on the Sabbath, Jesus demonstrated that the day was not meant to be a burden for people, but a blessing.  Another reason Jesus healed on the Sabbath was to challenge the legalistic interpretation of the Sabbath laws. The Pharisees, who were the religious leaders of the time, had become so focused on following the letter of the law that they had lost sight of its true purpose. Jesus wanted to show them that the Sabbath was not about following strict rules, but about showing compassion and mercy to others.  Frequently Asked Questions  1. How did the religious leaders react to Jesus healing on the Sabbath?  The religious leaders of the time were often angered by Jesus’ actions. They accused him of breaking the Sabbath law and violating their religious traditions. They saw his healing miracles as a threat to their authority and a challenge to their interpretation of the law.  2. Did Jesus ever explain why he chose to heal on the Sabbath?  There is no record of Jesus explaining his actions directly. However, he did make it clear that he believed the Sabbath was meant to serve humanity, not the other way around. He also challenged the legalistic interpretation of the Sabbath laws, which may have been another reason for his actions.  3. Was Jesus the first person to heal on the Sabbath?  No, there were other healers who performed healing miracles on the Sabbath before Jesus. However, Jesus’ healing miracles were unique in that they often involved dramatic displays of power and authority, which made them particularly controversial.  4. Did Jesus only heal on the Sabbath?  No, Jesus performed healing miracles on other days as well. However, his decision to heal on the Sabbath was often a deliberate choice to challenge the religious traditions of his time.  5. What was the significance of Jesus healing on the Sabbath?  Jesus’ decision to heal on the Sabbath had several significant implications. It challenged the legalistic interpretation of the Sabbath laws, demonstrated the true purpose of the Sabbath as a day of rest and blessing, and showed the importance of compassion and mercy in the practice of faith.  6. Did Jesus always heal people immediately?  No, sometimes Jesus’ healing miracles took time to take effect. For example, in John 9, Jesus healed a man who had been blind from birth by rubbing mud on his eyes and telling him to go wash in the Pool of Siloam. The man’s sight was not immediately restored, but gradually improved over time.  7. Did Jesus ever refuse to heal someone?  There are examples in the Bible where Jesus did not perform healing miracles. For example, in Mark 6:5-6, Jesus was unable to perform miracles in his hometown because of the lack of faith among the people there.  8. Did Jesus ever use medicine to heal people?  No, there is no record of Jesus using medicine to heal people. His healing miracles were generally performed through the power of his words or his touch.  9. Did Jesus’ healing miracles have any lasting effects?  Yes, many of Jesus’ healing miracles had significant and lasting effects on the people he healed. For example, in Luke 17:11-19, Jesus healed ten lepers, and only one of them returned to thank him. That man was not only healed physically but also spiritually, as he came to recognize the power and authority of Jesus.  10. Can people still be healed miraculously today?  Many people still believe in the power of miraculous healing today. While not everyone receives physical healing, many people report feeling comforted and strengthened by their faith.  11. What can we learn from Jesus’ healing miracles?  Jesus’ healing miracles teach us the importance of showing compassion and mercy to others, and of remembering that the Sabbath was made for humanity, not the other way around. They also remind us that healing often involves not just physical restoration but spiritual and emotional healing as well.  12. How can we apply the lessons of Jesus’ healing miracles to our lives today?  We can apply the lessons of Jesus’ healing miracles by seeking to show compassion and mercy to others, and by recognizing the importance of rest and Sabbath time in our own lives. We can also seek to cultivate a spirit of faith and openness to the transformative power of God in our lives.

Nguyet Le's lifeless body was discovered in the walk-in freezer at the Arby's establishment in New Iberia earlier this month, according to our media partners at KATC.  In response to this tragic incident, Le's family is preparing to take legal action, claiming that her death could have been prevented.  Representing the Le family, attorney Paul Skrabanek from the Pierce Skrabanek law firm explained their decision to pursue legal recourse while speaking with KATC. Skrabanek stated that after speaking with authorities, it was revealed that there was an issue with the freezer door latch. Although he was not aware of the exact details, it appears that the door required routine propping open with a box of oil.  The family's lawyer also suggested that the combination of below-freezing temperatures and the inability to open the freezer door from the inside may have contributed to Le's demise. Skrabanek shared the preliminary findings from the coroner's office, stating that hypothermia was determined to be the cause of death. He further noted that investigating officers discovered a significant amount of blood on the door, indicating that Le had likely struggled to escape before succumbing to her condition.  According to the KATC report, an anonymous former employee revealed that the faulty freezer door had been a longstanding safety hazard at the workplace. The individual mentioned that the door had been broken for months, and despite numerous complaints and work orders, the issue remained unresolved. Tragically, Le was working alone at the time of the incident and was unable to seek assistance.  Le, a 63-year-old mother of four and a grandmother, had been contracted from Texas to work at the New Iberia location alongside her son. As if the story wasn't heartbreaking enough, it was her son who discovered her lifeless body when he returned to the store to begin the day's operations, as Skrabanek explained to KATC. Le had been performing some opening tasks before the rest of the crew arrived.  Pierce Skrabanek emphasized the importance of examining the freezer door at Arby's as the next step in their legal process. They have sent letters to Turbo Restaurants, the franchise owner, and are awaiting a response to proceed with the inspection.  KATC says they attempted to contact Turbo Restaurants but was unable to reach them. We have also reached out to the company to no avail.  The investigation into this tragic incident is still ongoing, and updates will be provided as new information is available.

Ismail Lagardien is a writer, columnist and political economist with extensive exposure and experience in global political economic affairs. He was educated at the London School of Economics, and holds a PhD in International Political Economy.  We have reached a point where there is little blue sky between the ANC and the EFF. This is most evident in the way that the politics of revenge, sometimes Biblical revenge, is spreading under the banners of these two political formations.  This may be because when Julius Malema was expelled from the ANC he took the ANC Youth League’s beliefs and values, including its rhetoric, with him and established the EFF. It became clear, early on in the life of the EFF, that they had become an outgrowth of the Youth League, and that the EFF’s policies were merely “a copy and paste from the ANCYL’s resolutions in 2011”.  It may also be because of a terribly misguided belief that revenge is a necessary recourse to justice that open hostility is a useful rallying cry for support, that “non-Africans” must, today, suffer the pain that “real Africans” have endured for centuries, and (at the far reaches of plausibility) that the state alone is responsible for wellbeing in society.  This is not an anti-state argument… it is simply to recall Benito Mussolini’s formulation of the totalitarian ideal: “everything in the State, nothing outside the State, nothing against the State.” We will get back to that below.  In recent months, the policy differences and elements of their respective programmes of action have bled into one, and there has been increasing speculation of coalitions between the two formations in national, provincial and local governments. (See here, here, and here).  While this rapprochement between the “broad church” that is the ANC, and the ersatz leftist (increasingly fascistic) EFF may be part of electoral pushing and shoving and Malema’s belief that he has to be president of South Africa, it is on the politics of revenge that is of greater, more immediate concern.  Let’s take a walk into some of the ideas about hatred…  Social hostility, hatred and revenge  Over the past several years there has been a rise in EFF propaganda expressed in crude hatred of white people (see report on slogan “kill all whites” and now-tired appeals from Andile Mngxitama’s political movements to kill whites) and more and more gaslighting of “non-African blacks” — specifically directed at South Africans of Asian heritage.  This prejudice has been extended insultingly via social media also to Africans who are described as “coconuts”, who speak English “with a Model C” accent, Jacob Zuma’s “clever blacks” or people who listened to particular radio station broadcasts — the so-called 702 blacks. As a footnote: the idea of a white genocide is a myth. South African society is marked by extreme violence, especially murder, across the population.  One way to understand this growing spread of violent prejudice and hatred is the way in which powerful rhetoric by monocratic leaders (dictators, autocrats or people who believe they have a divine right to govern) amount to social influence that establishes a range of prejudices from anti-semitism, racism, sexism or homophobia to outright vitriol and outbursts against people who are considered to be “outsiders”.  One explanation that intellectually eludes me is Freud’s “narcissism of sameness”. During the inter-war years, he wrote:  “The Jewish people, scattered everywhere, have rendered the most useful services to the civilisations of the countries that have been their hosts; but unfortunately all the massacres of the Jews in the Middle Ages did not suffice to make that period more peaceful and secure for their Christian fellows. When once the Apostle Paul had posited universal love between men as the foundation of his Christian community, extreme intolerance on the part of Christendom towards those who remained outside it became the inevitable consequence.”  What does sound plausible is that once South Africans were told we are all equal under law, this “sameness” provoked a probably greater intolerance. There are distinct echoes of this in the fact that Europeans arrived in southern Africa as a “same” group of colonisers (a solid white front), but would split into Afrikaans and English speakers — though not entirely. This split remains vaguely evident in the current differences between the Democratic Alliance and the Freedom Front Plus.  Another example of this comes from Anthony Sampson in the New York Times under the headline “South Africa: the Time Bomb Ticks” (in 1964!)  “The despair of the Africans is not derived simply from a harried and oppressed existence; it comes from the fact that they have been first lured into the Western world, and then shut out from it; that they have seen larger horizons, but have been pushed back into their back yards; that every day they feel aware of the humiliation of their race.”  In other words, you let people into the sameness, and as soon as they’re in, you take it away and divide them up… It’s difficult to wrap one’s mind around that completely…  South African society is marked by a battle between the past (past injustice) and the (just) future; the present becomes hallowed grounds for claims about innocence and guilt. The political economic way ahead into a just future begins with excoriating the guilty for past injustice and any resistance or objections are met with, or at least threatened with, violence. This is the space into which the politics of revenge steps.  We can start with a question: do you exact revenge, or do the victims and villains work to establish a stable, non-violent future?  One thing is for sure; violence and killing cannot solve social problems. The Atlantic community killed most all Nazis, and the Nazi movement in Europe during and after the Second World War, but the world is not rid of anti-semitism. I would venture a guess that if you killed every white supremacist, racism would not die, nor would patriarchy or misogyny end if you killed all males.  So there is no misunderstanding, we have to support the Constitution’s insistence that the injustices and wrongs of the past have to be rolled back. It is also important to stress that there can be no political-economic transformation without addressing the land question.  The naysayers might want to look at the history of land reforms as the start of political economic development across the world in varying ideological polities — see Taiwan from 1895 onward, or land reforms in Poland from 1764 well into the early 20th century. Poland’s The Land Reform Implementation Act of 1920, and the amendment of 1925, laid the legal foundations for land redistribution.  Land reform and distribution is not always just or benevolent. Sometimes it can lead to large-scale human and social disasters. The evidence for this is when Europeans appropriated land from indigenous people in North America, and when two land-people engineering projects during Mao’s Cultural Revolution led to millions of deaths. Maintenance of the status quo is no guarantee of a stable future in South Africa. Land redistribution is necessary but probably insufficient…  Suffer everyone: Punished for sins of the fathers  We are political prisoners of the past. South Africa’s past is one of European oppression and injustice in southern Africa, and at home in Europe, for what it’s worth.  It was in that past when our attitudes to others were shaped. White against black; Afrikaner against English-speakers; “non-African” against African… South Africa has become, then, a place of intense anger (not so much different from the age of anger that Pankaj Mishra so eloquently wrote about) and recrimination, with very distinct trends of vengefulness.  For their past injustices, and the suffering of black people, Julius Malema has embarked on revenge politics, a Biblical punishment for sins of the father. White people, and presumably non-Africans in general must suffer what black people suffered in the past. This, and not the Bill of Rights, seems to be the only way that there can be redress.  The ANC’s Panyaza Lesufi joins the ANC in targeting Afrikaans-language schools, less as a means to address mother-tongue instruction in indigenous languages, but because past injustices were codified in that language. Where genocide kills people, a people and their culture can be decimated by killing the languages that represent communities.  This politics of revenge is part of the clear fascist leanings of the EFF and the totalitarianism of the ANC. It brings them together.  Consider the ANC’s response to when communities sought to free themselves from the state enterprise formally responsible for the generation and supply of electricity, and generate their own power. The state’s response has been like saying; you have to get it from the state, and if the state can’t provide it you must suffer like everyone else.  Part of the state’s response to households generating solar energy is to tax it heavily and place it out of reach. The message here is you either get it from the state or you don’t get it at all. This is Mussolini’s formulation of the totalitarian ideal: “everything in the State, nothing outside the State, nothing against the State.”  This is not to say that taxation is bad, it is simply to state that South Africa has an energy crisis, compounded by a crisis of the state and extreme rent-seeking by elites. Those elites are precisely those inside and outside the state, including those in Parliament.  The EFF and ANC leaders share among them forms of capital (cultural, social, symbolic and economic) and that places them in positions of power and privilege.  To them, rolling back the injustices of the past is primarily a pecuniary pursuit, even if it takes bloodshed and violence, a position that Julius Malema has held since his days in the ANC, and that he has restated as leader of the EFF. Officials with the Henderson Police Department are searching for a man they believe is a fugitive who recently escaped from a Lima, Ohio prison with another inmate.  In a post on Facebook around 4:20 AM Wednesday morning, the Department said officers attempted to stop a car they believed was stolen and was occupied by the two escapees. The car fled the scene and wrecked on Camaro Drive. The two occupants got out of the vehicle and attempted to run away. One inmate, James Marion Lee was caught by officers and placed under arrest. The other, Bradley Gillespie (pictured above) managed to get away.  Get our free mobile app  Henderson Police say Gillespie has charges including "murder, breaking and entering, theft, assault, possession of drugs, escape, forgery, receiving stolen property, weapons offenses, and burglary." He is listed as 6’ tall, 200 pounds, 50 years old, appears to be bald, and was last seen wearing dark clothing.  According to our media partners, Eyewitness News, Evansville Police are also involved in the search after they were contacted by Henderson Police about someone who may have been trying to swim across the Ohio River along Old Henderson Road near Hickory Ridge.  Henderson Police have set up a perimeter around the area of Camaro Drive and are encouraging residents to be vigilant, lock their doors, and call 911 if they have any information that may help them locate Gillespie.  [Sources: Henderson Police Department on Facebook / Eyewitness News]

“Kooks need to learn to paddle for the whitewater instead of being a selfish person and ruin people's waves."  The New Smyrna surfer Eric Geiselman has been alternately slammed, and praised, after posting a short clip where he ollies a learner surfer’s head after the VAL has the misfortune to be paddling over the shoulder of a wave Geiselman is riding.  “Where’s ya head at?” writes thirty-five-year-old Geiselman of his expertly executed jump.  View this post on Instagram A post shared by Eric Geiselman (@ericgeiselman)  Fans and friends were divided, however, some lauding his dexterity and the lesson it served to a VAL who should’ve, theoretically at least, paddled towards the whitewater and to the shoulder of the wave while others were less kind.  For,  Jimmy Wilson, surf photographer: “Since the beginning of 2020, not one person has paddled towards the whitewater and attempted a duck dive.”  Raglansurf report, “That guy probably should’ve kept paddling instead of stopping in the lip I reckon.”  As well as,  “Kooks need to learn to paddle for the white water instead of being a selfish person and ruin people’s waves by paddling on the wall because they dont want to have a wave crashing on their dumb heads.”  “Love that Ollie bruv. It’s amazing how many looks actually think they fit in lineups. We got backpackers cluttering the lineups and roads down margs ATM after the Covid shit show.”  Against,  “Ollying a chicks head for a shit turn, wow, wouldn’t be showing that on the internet.”  “Horrible behaviour, this could have gone wrong and you could have really injured bad the guy or even have killed him just for your ego. Where is the example for the kids and the other surfer from those pro surfers? That’s why the line up are becoming so bad and full of people behaving super bad. A real man would have just gone straight and waste one of the 1000000000 waves you will get in your life and then speak with the guy in order to avoid this to happen again. But yes being a good surfer doesn’t mean necessary being a good person and this the end is all that matter in the life, good surfers is full out there, you are just one of the 1000. Hopefully you apologize to show this rubbish!”  “What about fins? And what about longboard surfers head? Do ya think it’s worth enough a wave for that risky trick? A longboard is not as easy to manage than a short board. Where’s the real surfing? Respect.”  “Should have archived this footy. Just promotes other entitled kids fortunate enough to grow up on the beach to send people to hospital. Lame, intentional and warrants a black eye.”  “Whoa. You almost injured someone badly and are proud enough to post. Bad attitude.”  “Seen some pretty serious fin caused injuries before soooooo yeah maybe don’t do that to someone.”  It’s a vexed issue, of course, and your opinion might be shaped by whatever has happened to you during your most recent surf experience.  Today, for instance, a gal dropped in on someone while I was paddling out and landed on my head after her feet failed to find the wax.  I surfaced amid the tangle of fibreglass and leash cord to be told to get out of her “fucking way.”  Yesterday, I’d be inclined to side with the happy soul on the shoulder; today less so.  You? West Hollywood is set to select its first-ever Drag Laureate to serve as an official ambassador for the city’s robust drag culture, following an updated approval of the program by the City Council in March 2023.  The Drag Laureate program was initially proposed during an October 2020 City Council meeting, with an intention to highlight and promote West Hollywood’s drag arts through a designated representative. The application for the program, released in September 2022, was briefly halted to incorporate community feedback.  Once selected, the Drag Laureate will serve a two-year term from July 16, 2023, to June 30, 2025, with their tenure starting on International Drag Day. This honorary role includes a commitment to enhance the presence of drag culture, inspire emerging drag artists, and promote partnerships within West Hollywood’s business and community organizations.  The Drag Laureate will be expected to attend approximately 15 city-approved events per year, including key city events such as WeHo Pride and West Hollywood Day, and local business community events. The Laureate will also organize an annual event to celebrate drag history and culture.  The position comes with a $12,500 annual honorarium and a $2,500 stipend for the yearly event. These funds will cover any costs related to the Laureate’s participation in events, activities, and required insurances, as well as expenses associated with the annual event.  A selection panel, comprised of the Arts and Cultural Affairs Commission and a member from the Transgender Advisory Board, evaluated 13 applications from both Drag Kings and Queens. The applications were assessed based on several criteria, including a significant connection to West Hollywood, quality of cover letter, introductory video, qualifications and experience, visual portfolio, performance excellence, and recognition of the applicant’s work locally, regionally, and nationally.  Staff will compile the scores and present the applicants in ranking order at the Arts and Cultural Affairs Commission meeting on May 25, 2023. The Commission will then recommend one applicant for the West Hollywood Drag Laureate to the City Council for final approval.  Here are the 13 applicants and the unedited cover letters they submitted:  Aunduh  My name is Aunduh, and that name itself has a history to it. When I first started drag, it was Aunduh Dix, and then Aunduh Estemated, to finally Aunduh. I know I’d be a great fit as West Hollywood’s Drag Laureate, not only because of my personality but also because of my work and education history. From my experiences and projects in community college to my recent parlay into music and comedy have all helped me in not only being comfortable with speaking front of large groups, but also interacting with my community.  While I attended Fresno City College, I created a student organization along with a few students called The Latino Student Organization (LASO); and it was in creating this that we created our own rules of order and held several fundraisers and events for the organization as well as participating in community service events. I was also part of PUENTE which was a program geared at bridging the gap between community college and university education. It was with PUENTE that I spoke at several fundraisers and group events, as well as had some of my poetry featured by deans that attended. Even in high school I helped out with community events and outreach, but I feel Fresno City nurtured my passion for it. It was also this time in my life that worked for the county as an HIV/AIDS peer counselor, where we would go into the community and attend events where we would discuss prevention and education about HIV/AIDS.  I then attended the University of California, Merced where I was a founding member and the first openly gay student to graduate from there. While at UCM, I worked as a tour guide for the admissions department of the University and would not only give tours, but would also travel throughout California to represent the University, discuss my experiences, and boost our enrollment; I maintained this job throughout my time at UCM till I graduated. At UCM I was also employed as an orientation leader my last semester; in this job we would help to acclimate new students to the university as well as help their parents to feel at ease with leaving their students with us. And I would say that it was in my outreach at UCM that I found my love for helping underrepresented and underprivileged communities, admissions sent us individually to various schools around the area that did not have much representation in terms of higher education.  After receiving my bachelor’s degree, I briefly worked with Autistic children as behavioral therapist and then later for the State of California Department of Motor Vehicles as a licensing registration examiner. It was around this time that I discovered my love of drag and of the gay community as a whole; this was also the time of Meet In The Middle which was a protest to overturn Prop 8 and a march of which I participated in. And during this time, I attended my first Pride in WeHo; one in which I felt free, safe, and like I finally belonged.  It is from this feeling of freedom, safety, and belonging that I have built my drag persona and my approach towards being a representative of the queer community as a whole. Growing up in a rural area, I know first hand the opposition one might receive just for existing and I want to be the person that lightens that load for others and to remind them that they not only deserve to be who they but that they have an unalienable right to do so. And I can truly say that that feeling for me was birthed and nurtured while becoming a drag queen in West Hollywood, a place where some think might be superficial, but I have found to be the most welcoming and loving of any city I’ve gone to.  I wrote a song titled: Born To Be Queen, and it’s about how we’re all born to be queens in our own way and it’s rooted in a story about my mom. When I was younger I wanted the ruby slippers, and she was going to get them for me, but before she did she said : “I want you to know something, some people are going to like you for them and some people are going to hate you but no matter what I’ll always love you.” And for me, love is and always will be the key to battling any kind of adversity; and Drag is an expression of self love.  And in terms that of BIPOC representation, I was raised with family members that were activists and that worked alongside Delores Huerta and others; and because they were in college when I was young, they’d bring around people from all different backgrounds that we viewed as family. And understand that terms like Black Excellence aren’t meant to divide us, but to make up for the years of being told otherwise.  Also, recently I’ve traveled the US to promote my music, and because of that I’ve visited various cities and Prides that are nowhere near as large as West Hollywood, but still help in the progress of queer culture. It is also from my experiences in Albuquerque and Charolette that I discovered the esteem that comes with representing West Hollywood; and that is an esteem I’d like to continue to uphold. Queens may be born into royalty, but they cannot govern without love, inspiration, or people, and truly you cannot be tyrant and expect change. Change only comes from love and respect, and it is that love and respect that will guide me as West Hollywood’s Drag Laureate.
